did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Consists mainly of letters by Roosevelt to a variety of correspondents, but also includes several autographs, photographs, one printed item, and two documents.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: American politician and author, U.S. President from 1901-1908.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Consists mainly of letters by Roosevelt to a variety of correspondents, but also includes several autographs, photographs, one printed item, and two documents. Letters span Roosevelt's career, briefly documenting his activities as governor of New York, Civil Service Commissioner, Commissioner of the New York City Police, Assistant Secretary of the U.S. Navy, Vice President, President, and, in his political retirement, editor in turn at The Outlook and Metropolitan magazines and the Kansas City Star newspaper. Correspondence deals with the handling of internal American political affairs, including dealings with Civil War veterans and a governors' conference on U.S. natural resources; letters to editors concerning books and articles Roosevelt was publishing or being asked to write; and a few letters on religious matters, including a substantial letter on the U.S. government's position vis-à-vis Catholic affairs in the Philippines.

Photographs show Roosevelt and a companion on an excursion in rocky country; and a set of proofs for color postcards documents scenes from Roosevelt's trip to Africa (1910). With the proofs are a contract for printing the images as postcards, an advertisement for the postcard set, and a cover letter from the printer for the proofs. The printed item is an inspirational message Roosevelt wrote for U.S. troops in 1917; the document is a Thanksgiving Day proclamation issued by Roosevelt in 1899 as Governor of New York. Also included in the collection is correspondence between W.J. Crawford and Robert William Glenroie Vail concerning the building of the collection.

Also, Roosevelt's reading copy of a speech delivered at the Ithaca Hotel on October 24, 1910, typed with handwritten corrections in pencil. The speech both attacks trusts and discusses the 1910 New York gubernatorial race between Democrat John Alden Dix and Republican Henry L. Stimson. Also, five photographs of Roosevelt at the Ithaca Hotel; and a photograph of Roosevelt in Albany in 1883, with Assemblyman O'Neil of Franklin County, Assemblyman Isaac L. Hunt of Jefferson County, George Spinney of the New York Times, and Assemblyman Walter Howe of New York.
Also includes a replica of the original Teddy bear.

odd.head: NOTES
odd.p: Large collection of books by and about Roosevelt is also held in the repository.

did.unittitle: Photo of two men leading horses across a rocky outcropping. The man in the front appears to be Theodore Roosevelt (3 prints)
Photo of two men leading horses across a rocky outcropping. The man in the front appears to be Theodore Roosevelt (large print)

Photo of Roosevelt in Albany in 1883, with Assemblyman O'Neil of Franklin County, Assemblyman Isaac L. Hunt of Jefferson County, George Spinney of the New York Times, and Assemblyman Walter Howe of New York (5 x 7" print)
Article in the Thursday, February 5, 1953 New York Times Newspaper advertising the restoration of Roosevelt's home on Sagamore Hill
Summary of the Roosevelt Collection housed in the Cornell Rare Books and Manuscripts Library
Typescript of speech given by Roosevelt in Ithaca, New York, along with photographs of the event.
Rochester Democrat and Chronicle newspaper showing post election day coverage of the Roosevelt win.
Four-color proofs for postcards produced from photographs of Roosevelt's trip to Africa, mainly showing scenes of big game hunting.

Roosevelt expresses regret that H.C. King will be resigning

The letter details Roosevelt's thoughts on the issue of removing Catholic friars from the Philippine Islands

Roosevelt discusses the conservation of the Nation's natural resources

Sender: Theodore Roosevelt
A letter from President Roosevelt regarding the need for more men of ability to lead the aggressive forces of Christianity

Sender: Theodore Roosevelt
Letter discussing a pamphlet on birds. Roosevelt disagrees with the explanation of why crows have only one dark coloring and no "protective variation"

Sender: Theodore Roosevelt
The teachings of the New Testament

Sender: Theodore Roosevelt
Contains photocopies of all letters

Sender: S. Barchak, The Cushman Company, Springfield, Mass.
Cover letter for proofs of postcards on Roosevelt's trip to Africa. With this are the proofs, plus 2 copies of a contract between Barchak and The Phelps Publishing Company to print the postcards (contract dated June 4, 1910).
